column1: During exercise, muscle fatigue occurs for several physiological reasons
One major cause is the accumulation of lactic acid, which is produced when glucose is broken down without sufficient oxygen
This acid can interfere with muscle contraction and lead to decreased performance
Another factor is the depletion of muscle glycogen stores, which provide energy for muscle contractions
The nervous system also plays a role, as it becomes less efficient at signaling muscles to contract over time
This neural fatigue can limit the force and speed of muscle contractions
Additionally, there is an increase in hydrogen ions, which can lower the pH in muscles and impair their function
These factors collectively contribute to the sensation and physiological changes associated with muscle fatigue
Understanding these causes helps in developing strategies to delay or mitigate muscle fatigue during exercise
